A cost-effective interactive 3D virtual reality system applied to military live firing training

A cost-effective interactive 3D virtual reality system applied to military live firing training

  • Kaushal Kumar Bhagat1,
  • Wei-Kai Liou2 &
  • Chun-Yen Chang  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2373-20041,2,3 

Virtual Reality volume 20, pages127–140(2016)Cite this article

  • 3300 Accesses

  • 38 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The goal of the present study was to develop a cost-effective, man–machine digital interface, to improve students’ real-world firing range training, results, and achievement scores. A serious game-based learning environment was developed, integrating invisible laser infrared technology, 1:1 real-scale rifle guns with recoil effects, as well as 3D interactive virtual reality (VR) military training digital information content, to train students in military live firing. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed design, students’ performance, in terms of their learning achievement and learning motivation, was examined. One hundred and sixty high school students from Taiwan were divided into four individual groups of 40 students each, with one control group and three experimental groups (EG1, EG2, and EG3). The data were analyzed by one-way analysis of variance. The results of this cost-effective 3D VR showed significantly better learning motivation, learning outcomes, and positive impacts on users’ actual live firing achievement scores.

Introduction

This work integrated invisible laser infrared technology, 1:1 real-scale rifle guns with recoil effects, and 3D interactive virtual reality (VR) military training digital information content. The use of digital information technology in education has given birth to a new generation of educational design patterns. However, compared to other subjects, the use of military training courses, which combine research and digital information technology, is still lacking. The goal of this study was to develop a prototype simulation-based training concept, to improve users’ real-world firing range skills and results.

The challenge for such a simulation is how to provide the learner with experience in real-world firing range skills. Currently, most digital real-world firing range systems implement the use of visible laser tracking technology as their core technology (Hagman 2000). Although different from the actual trajectory path of a bullet, a laser light’s straight-line property is, nevertheless, suitable in simulating the resulting trajectory in live firing training (US Department of Defense 2013) as shown in Fig. 1. In this study, we only focus on basic live firing training. Dynamic influences such as rain, wind, and sunlight effects will be presented in future stages of this study.

The main problem of a visible laser point is that it provides unnecessary reference coordinates for the learner to correct their trajectory (Liou and Lee 2012). Likewise, the reality of gun recoil is an important factor the learner must deal with during actual shooting (Wolff et al. 2003). Hence, we adopt invisible lasers, 1:1 real-scale guns with the recoil effect devices, and totally immersive 3D VR technology in this work; these units, together with a 3D VR real-world firing range program, supply learners with an immersive training exercise. By combining the three technologies, invisible laser image acquisition, gun recoil, and 3D VR, we have succeeded in developing an economic and effective digital real-world firing range system (suitable for any basic-level training unit utilizing rifle and live firing training). To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed design, students’ performances, in terms of their learning achievement and learning motivation, are examined.

Serious game and its effectiveness

With the recent advancement in technology, serious games, also known as digital game-based learning, have attracted much attention to the field of education. Serious games attempt to deliver engaging learning environments using gaming interfaces that are familiar to the end users (Csete et al. 2004; Van Der Spek et al. 2011). According to Marsh (2011), “serious games are digital games, simulations, virtual environments and mixed reality/media that provide opportunities to engage in activities through responsive narrative/story, gameplay or encounters to inform, influence, for well-being, and/or experience, to convey meaning. The quality or success of serious games is characterized by the degree to which purpose has been fulfilled. Serious games are identified along a continuum from games for purpose at one end, through experiential environments with minimal or no gaming characteristics for experience at the other end” (p. 63). In another definition, Miller et al. (2011) defined serious games as “games primarily focused on education rather than entertainment” (p. 1425). Hummel et al. (2011) mentioned that serious games are purposively designed to educate and train for learning.

Many empirical research studies point out the positive outcomes of serious games as they improve learning outcome (Hummel et al. 2011; Ku et al. 2014; Sánchez and Olivares 2011; Sung and Hwang 2013; Sung et al. 2015), enhance students’ learning motivation (Hwang and Wu 2012; Kebritchi et al. 2010; Lim 2008; Papastergiou 2009; Sung and Hwang 2013; Sung et al. 2015; Wijers et al. 2008), help in the development of skills (Garris et al. 2002), and promote student engagement (Huizenga et al. 2009; Hung et al. 2014; Lim 2008; Wang and Chen 2010). It can be seen that serious games encompass a wealth of potential to be integrated into formal and informal learning settings.

Many research studies and reports advocate the use of serious games for military training purpose. For example, Lim and Jung (2013) stated that virtual military training is one of the major objectives of military serious games; they advocate for military serious games as they save resources in terms of time and costs. Hsu (2010) mentioned that serious games, when aligned with military training, enhanced the fighting skills of US military recruits and also protected them from mental stress. Simulation games in military training can provide a real-life experience, without harming any life or equipment. In addition, they can save many millions of dollars for training purposes (Kennedy 1999). The US Army’s Future Holistic Training Environment Live Synthetic program has adopted a new approach to providing cheaper and more effective training for the future soldiers by integrating combat training with various simulations (Szondy 2014). National Post (2013) reported that the Canadian military adopted video simulations, including commercial games such as call of duty for enhancing shooting skills and also for cost-cutting purposes. Whitney et al. (2014) reviewed the effectiveness of game-based training for soldiers. They concluded that empirical evidence involving the effectiveness of computer game-based training for soldiers was very limited.

From the above literature review, two conclusions can be drawn. First, serious games have great underlying potentials and thus may be integrated in formal and informal settings for teaching and training purposes. Second, although there have been studies that included serious games for military training purposes, they are limited and need to be explored further in terms of education and real-life results. Thus, in the present study, we developed a serious game-based learning environment by integrating a 3D interactive VR and military training course with digital information content to train the students for live firing.

System design

This work integrates infrared technology, 1:1 real-scale rifle guns with recoil effects, and 3D interactive VR military training digital software to develop an economical and effective technique for rifle real-world firing range as shown in Fig. 2.

An economical and convenient solution

Today, traditional shooting practice is being replaced by real-world firing range systems, which combine digital information technology/simulation gun systems. Digitally simulated real-world firing range systems use human–system interfaces, for interactive operations, to replicate live firing training.

The armed troops of many countries have succeeded in the development of large-scale computer simulations of live firing training. These provide those armed troops with the opportunity to execute simulations of live firing training. Although those systems provided valuable assistance for training needs, their price and volume are a major concern for many users; a common digital real-world firing range system, with basic functions, costs upwards of 100,000 US dollars and is not portable. Therefore, how to make an economical and convenient solution for digital real-world firing range systems is an attractive topic for many researchers. This work develops an economic and effective digital real-world firing range system for any basic-level training unit utilizing rifle and live firing training.

Totally immersive effect

Important factors, such as gun recoil effect, cannot be included in most traditional simulation shooting practice (such as US Patent No. 4050166 A). However, the reality of gun recoil is a very important factor the learner must deal with during actual shooting (Wolff et al. 2003). Hence, in this work, we adopt 1:1 real-scale guns, with the recoil effect device on simulation rifle gun. This unit, together with a 3D VR real-world firing range program, supplies learners with a simulation-based training exercise.

Invisible laser infrared (ILI) technology

Invisible laser infrared tracking technology may help learners to adopt actual shooting techniques to hit targets more precisely. Previously, most digital real-world firing range systems implemented the use of visible laser tracking technology as their core technology (Hagman 2000). The main problem of a visible laser point is that it provides unnecessary reference coordinates for the learner to correct their trajectory (Liou and Lee 2012). Thus, training utilizing a visible laser practice system will have a negative impact on shooting essentials. Learners, utilizing an invisible laser, can be better prepared for essential and basic real-world firing.

Technical characteristics

By combining three technologies (invisible laser image acquisition, gun recoil, and 3D VR), we have attempted to demonstrate a useful technique for military live firing training. This research technology is divided into three sections, described below.

Invisible laser infrared (ILI) technology

This work developed and incorporated an auto-positioning and ILI spot tracking method for the purpose of feasibility to use in various human–machine interface system operations. We proposed a method to achieve a quick auto-calibration, which gives a fast positioning and tracking for solving an ILI tracking problem, by utilizing a common webcam. This method is developed by coordinating the projector’s screen with the computer’s screen, and works between two coordinate systems. By combining a common webcam with visual identification and geometry conversion, we can capture a snapshot of a projector’s screen. After a quick analysis and vertices calculation, a conversion matrix can be obtained, which is an important procedure for the conversion of the ILI spot from external coordinate to internal coordinate. ILI tracking technology promotes the learner to adopt shooting essentials to hit the target precisely.

Image acquisition

The ILI unit emits an invisible laser infrared spot on the screen. The ILI spot is then detected by a data processing unit through an image capturing unit. The image is utilized to display the output image from the data processing unit. The image acquisition technology, utilized in this study, is a 390–700-nm-visible-light filter. This light filter lens may effectively filter the 390–700-nm-visible-light on the screen image. The wavelength of the invisible laser infrared spot is higher than the 390–700-nm visible-light. This allows the optics photography function to trace the ILI emitter spot on the screen image. Utilizing this spot tracking provides the coordinates of the ILI spot with good precision.

The internal coordinates with external coordinate convert operation

The ILI emission unit is for emitting an invisible laser infrared spot image on the screen. Based on the coordinates of the ILI spot (detected through the image capture unit and the coordinate converter operation), the internal coordinates may be turned into external coordinates on the data processing unit. The location of the ILI spot, through image acquisition calibration, as well as an internal and external coordinate converter operation, can guide the cursor output by the data processing unit, via on-screen imaging to launch synchronous coordinates with the ILI spot.

Calibration technology

The calibration utilizes an automatic four-corner localization method to adjust the coordinates of the mouse cursor on the screen (mathematical matrix transformation). This automatic calibration only takes a few seconds each time. The coordinate of the mouse cursor is followed by a defined sequence for completing the calibration. When a corner is captured by the camera, the tracking process can be started; at this time, the cursor tracking is set up completely. Once the calibration stage is completed, the system starts its main loop. The main loop consists of a series of image manipulations that are performed on each frame and result in an array of coordinates pertaining to coordinate points on the screen. After image processing and computer software program operations, the movement of an image can be transformed by a cursor command to guide the invisible laser infrared spot precisely as shown in Fig. 3.

After the image acquisition and automatic four-corner localization methods are complete, the system can adjust the coordinates of the internal coordinates with external coordinate conversion operation, as shown in Fig. 4. Then, the ILI spot on the screen, emitted from muzzle, can be directly transformed into a mouse cursor position and click command to guide the bullet impact precisely as shown in Fig. 5.

Simulation rifle gun

The second technology involves installing an invisible laser infrared emitter source on the muzzle, and a recoil effect device on simulation T91 rifle gun. The T91 assault rifle is produced by 205th Armory in Taiwan. It incorporates features from the M16 and AR-18. The T91 is lighter and shorter with modern features. This rifle has a 6-position telescopic stock, allowing for the installation of different kinds of equipment depending on individual requirements.

The recoil effect device is made possible through a gas power system. Before shooting, the gas is filled into the gas magazine. During shooting, the gas inside the magazine will drive barrel firing recoil. By linking invisible laser infrared emitter source on the muzzle, and a recoil effect device on simulation T91 rifle gun, a true shooting experience is provided. This gives the learner a realistic scenario to achieve a true simulation of a real-world firing range, as shown in Fig. 6.

3D VR real-world firing range software

The 3D VR real-world firing range software in this study, as shown in Fig. 7, utilizes the Unity game engine. Unity is a powerful game development engine. We selected this software because it is cross-platform software well supported by a vast ecosystem of art and design resources. For independent developers, this software breaks time and cost barriers for creating works as needed.

Real-world firing range training mode

The digital real-world firing range software is divided into five training modes as follows:

Training modes 1–3 are 25-, 75-, and 175-m fixed target training mode, respectively. Each training mode, 1–3, has a different shooting range for the learner to practice live firing at different distances. These distances and scenarios were designed based on true live firing ranges. Learner can be trained in these practice modes as if he were in a true firing range as shown in Fig. 8.

Training modes 4 and 5 are mobile target training modes. The training purpose on these modes is for the learner to practice advanced shooting skill as the target is not fixed in position (i.e., the target is moving). These modes include 75 and 175 m targets for training. All scenarios in these modes are also designed based on true firing range training as shown in Fig. 9.

The other important function in this software is that the system can record the bullet impact points automatically, as shown in Fig. 10a, b. Based on this function, trainers can observe information about the learner’s learning status and learning outcomes. Following the records stored by the system, trainers may develop teaching strategies, correct the learner’s weak point(s) on shooting, and improve the learner’s shooting and essential skills.

Combat training mode

In our combat training mode, we have two shooting training modes. The first is a moving enemy attack mode (see Fig. 11). The purpose of this mode, for the learner, is to establish the basics of shooting skills, become familiar with shooting essentials, and increase the learner’s motivation on learning.

The second mode is a fixed enemy attack mode (see Fig. 12). The purpose of this mode is for the learner to practice shooting essentials and hit the target precisely. The fixed enemy attack distance was designed as per the fixed target training mode, 25-, 75-, and 175-m. The purpose of this fixed enemy attack mode is almost the same as the fixed target training mode as mentioned above. The learner needs to concentrate on their shooting essentials to hit the enemy precisely. It was found that most learners are willing to practice and practice on their own without any coercion.

Methods

Research design and sample

The present study followed a post-test only quasi-experimental design. A total of 160 (males = 90, females = 70) Taiwanese high school students, aged 15–16 years, were divided into four individual groups of 40 students, including: one control group (CG) and three experimental groups (EG1, EG2, and EG3). All the participants in this study had previous gaming experience. The independent variable in the present study was the training mode (i.e., ordinary real-world firing range vs. real-world firing range mode in 3D interactive VR vs. combat training mode vs. both real-world firing range mode and combat training mode). The dependent variables were learning outcome and motivation.

Instruments

In the present study, we used OpenCV and Unity as software to develop automatic calibration and 3D real-world firing range, respectively. In addition, a simulation T91 gun, a laptop (with webcam), a projector, and a projector screen were used as hardware. The learner’s learning outcome was taken from the shooting scores, from a true real-world firing range, as shown in Fig. 13. In order to measure learner’s motivation, a questionnaire was developed. To maintain the content validity, a group of experts from the field of educational technology reviewed the items. The questionnaire was constructed based on the reviewer’s comments and suggestions. A pilot test of the questionnaire was conducted with 70 participants. The resulting questionnaire consisted of ten items, which is included as “Appendix” section. The overall Cronbach’s α (internal consistency) for the questionnaire was 0.796.

Procedure

Classes were 8 h (2 h per week) in length, for a total of 4 weeks in the experimental course with different didactics. In the first stage, teacher started the automatic calibration software as mentioned above. As the calibration stage was completed, the movement of bullet impact points could be transformed by a cursor command to guide the ILI spots precisely. The students utilized firearms installed with ILI emitter sources, on the muzzles, and recoil effect devices on said simulation T91 guns. In the next stage, teacher started the 3D VR live firing training software, utilizing the Unity game engine.

The CG adopted ordinary real-world firing range didactics. The other three experimental groups adopted ILI tracking technology, 1:1 real-scale guns with recoil effects and 3D interactive VR digital information software in class. The difference between the three experimental groups was that the first experimental group (EG1) adopted only the real-world firing range mode in 3D interactive VR digital information; the second experimental group (EG2) adopted only combat training mode; and the third experimental group (EG3) adopted both real-world firing range mode and combat training mode. The classes focused on serious game-based learning strategies for teaching activities designed to create a human–machine interactive learning environment for learners by using digital learning; after which, users experienced a real-world firing range.

Data analysis

One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to test for statistically significant differences between the experimental group and the CG. All analyses were conducted using the statistical package for the social sciences version 21 (SPSS 21). The statistical significance level was set at p < 0.05.

Results and discussion

Learning outcome

As shown in Table 1, there was a statistically significant difference between the groups for learning outcome as indicated by one-way ANOVA [F (3156) = 58.10, p < .05] due to different modes of training. The calculated effect size (eta squared, η 2) is 0.52, which is considered to be a large effect (Cohen 1988). Furthermore, a post hoc least significant difference (LSD) analysis was also conducted to evaluate the pairwise differences among the means. The results showed that students in EG3 scored significantly (p < .01) higher than EG1, EG2, and CG (as shown in Table 2). This indicated that the experimental group (EG3), which adopted both real-world firing range mode in 3D VR and combat training mode, performed better in the post-test than the students of the other groups (EG1, EG2, and CG). In addition, there were differences in the means among the different modes of VR training we tested. Similar to the previous research findings, Hummel et al. (2011), Ku et al. (2014), and Sung et al. (2015), the present study concluded that serious game-based learning improved the learning outcome of the learners.

Learning motivation

As shown in Table 3, there was a statistically significant difference between the groups for learning motivation as indicated by one-way ANOVA [F (3156) = 160.015, p < .05] due to different modes of training. The calculated effect size (eta squared, η 2) is 0.75, which is considered to be a large effect (Cohen 1988). Furthermore, a post hoc least significant difference (LSD) analysis was also conducted. The results showed that students in both EG2 and EG3 scored significantly (p < .01) higher than those in EG1 and CG (as shown in Table 4). This indicated that the experimental group (EG2), which adopted only combat training mode, and the experimental group (EG3), which adopted both real-world firing range mode in 3D VR and combat training mode, were more highly motivated than the students of the other groups. The outcomes of this study are consistent with the studies by Hwang and Wu (2012), Kebritchi et al. (2010), and Wijers et al. (2008), which highlighted that serious game-based learning promoted students’ learning motivation.

Relationship between learner’s learning outcome and learning motivation

We also calculated the correlation between learner’s learning outcome and learning motivation, which was 0.509. This showed a strong positive significant relationship between the two measures.

Conclusions

We found learner’s learning outcomes, learning motivation and final performance, when utilizing the innovative 3D interactive virtual system, were better than those in traditional live firing training. This study presents a useful and cost-effective system for the military live firing training. The real-world firing range mode not only helps the learner to immerse in the scenario, via the execution simulation of live firing training, but can, likewise, store bullet impact point records. Following these records, the trainer may develop teaching strategies, correct the learner’s weak point on shooting, and improve the learner’s shooting skill and essentials. There is still more research that needs to be done. As we look toward the future, we are starting by providing a cost-effective interactive 3D VR real-world firing range system to schools, which can easily add this innovation with a projector, screen, and PC equipment, already found in most classrooms.

The other interesting phenomenon is that the students prefer to be educated in the combat training mode, as this mode is very interesting to the learner. Users were often found practicing and enjoying themselves, in this mode, without any coercion or suggestions. As we continue to investigate, this stated self-motivation may be the reason for the improvement in students’ shooting essential and basic skills imperceptibly.

Future research, already in progress, examines the relationships between motivation and learning outcomes in real-world firing ranges. The present study only focuses on basic real-world fire training mode. Dynamic influences, including rain, wind, and sunlight effects, need to be presented in the next stage of study. Another limitation of the current research is that the study pool focused on high school students, and does not touch upon the subject of how well it may motivate or improve the military skills of someone who has joined the military. These shortcomings and concerns should be included in future research.

As mentioned above, real-world firing range mode can increase learning performances, and combat training mode can increase learning motivation. To take advantage to make up for the shortcomings of both training modes, this study also adopts both real-world firing range mode and combat training mode in class. VR training mode was better than the non-VR training mode, and even that our hybrid training model had the best performance scores and was one of the best for improving learner’s motivation.

In this study, we use invisible laser infrared technology, to develop its interaction and application on a real-world firing range system. It is demonstrated that the system’s performance positively impacts a students’ achievement in military training courses. Our solution is constructed with simple and cheap devices, including a charge-coupled device (CCD) camera, invisible laser infrared source, a camera carriage, a special camera lens, a webcam (with a resolution of 1280 × 1024 pixels or above), and invisible laser infrared point tracking software. In addition, this study uses a simulation, 1:1 real-scale gun, with actual recoil effects. The outcomes show there is significantly better learning motivation, learning outcomes, and positive impacts on learner’s live firing achievements. This system succeeds as an economical and effective training technique for military live firing training. These results provide important references for further studies related to the future conduct of military training curriculum design and digital learning teaching models for 3D interactive VR courses.
